page.title: 16CLATTERBRIDGE HOSPITAL
page.content: In 1836 the site was used for a workhouse and in 1888 accommodation was provided for the treatment of infectious diseases in an isolation unit. The hospital facilities were improved in 1920 when new wards and a new nurses' home were built. In 1930 the site was taken over by Cheshire County Council and was renamed Clatterbridge General Hospital. Since the opening of Arrowe Park Hospital in 1982, Clatterbridge has lost its accident and maternity units, but has increased its specialisation in particular areas of medicine, especially the treatment of cancer. Part of the hospital is now occupied by St. John's Hospice for the terminally ill which is funded by charity work carried out by local people.
